melancholy.used_in_sentence: My massive homework amount makes me melancholy.

abhor.definition: to hate very much; to detest utterly

defunct.definition: no longer effective or useful; having ceased to exist

refute.definition: to show to be false; to deny the truth of
refute.used_in_sentence: I refute the claims that I don't have a functioning brain.

exacerbate.used_in_sentence: I will not exacerbate the unusablness of my brain.

chagrin.used_in_sentence: Ben was filled with chagrin when he broke the typewriter.

petulant.used_in_sentence: Anthony is very petulant in math class.

sublime.used_in_sentence: The sublime elegance of a penguin in a tutu gracefully ice-skating under a shower of popcorn had the audience questioning their popcorn-induced hallucinations.

tribulation.used_in_sentence: Anthony faces tribulation not to talk all math class.

fret.definition: to cause or to suffer emotional stress
fret.used_in_sentence: The squirrel fretted about its acorn collection, unaware that a jazz band of chipmunks was using them as maracas for their forest concert.

deter.definition: to discourage or prevent from acting
deter.used_in_sentence: My idiocy deters me from getting an A+.

winnow.used_in_sentence: The hiring manager had to winnow the stack of resumes, removing those that didn't meet the basic qualifications for the position.

lucid.used_in_sentence: Despite the complex subject matter, the professor's explanation was so lucid that even beginners could grasp the concept.

berate.used_in_sentence: The coach had to resist the urge to berate his team after their poor performance, knowing that harsh criticism wouldnâ€™t improve their morale.

exorbitant.used_in_sentence: The restaurant's prices were so exorbitant that many customers left upon seeing the menu, unwilling to pay such unreasonable amounts for a meal.

circumvent.definition: to manage to get around, especially by ingenuity
circumvent.used_in_sentence: The clever student found a way to circumvent the long lunch line by using the side entrance to the cafeteria.

meticulous.definition: marked by extreme care in the consideration of details
meticulous.used_in_sentence: My grandmother's quilt showed her meticulous attention to detail, with every stitch perfectly aligned.

digression.definition: the act of leaving the main subject in writing or a speech
digression.used_in_sentence: During his speech about space exploration, the scientist made a brief digression to explain how satellites work.

pertain.definition: to be appropriate to something; to belong as a part of something
pertain.used_in_sentence: These safety rules specifically pertain to the chemistry lab and must be followed during all experiments.

miscreant.definition: one who behaves criminally or viciously
miscreant.used_in_sentence: The miscreant who spray-painted the school wall was caught on security cameras and duly punished.

resilient.definition: tending to recover from misfortune or change
resilient.used_in_sentence: Though she failed her first attempt at the driving test, Sydney proved resilient and passed on her second try.

taciturn.used_in_sentence: The new student remained taciturn during the first week of class, observing his classmates silently from the back row.

malady.used_in_sentence: The strange malady kept him home from school for a week before doctors could diagnose it.

fluctuate.definition: to change continuously; to rise and fall
fluctuate.used_in_sentence: Gas prices tend to fluctuate throughout the year, rising in summer and falling in winter.

persevere.used_in_sentence: Despite the rainy weather and difficult terrain, the hikers decided to persevere and reach the mountain summit.

eschew.used_in_sentence: After his doctor's stern warning, James decided to eschew sugary drinks and switched to water instead.

frugal.used_in_sentence: Being frugal with her savings allowed Maria to eventually buy her dream house despite her modest income.

obfuscate.used_in_sentence: The politician tried to obfuscate the truth by using complex jargon and vague statements.

propensity.definition: an intense natural inclination or preference
propensity.used_in_sentence: Sarah's propensity for solving puzzles led her to become a successful CIA codebreaker.

venerate.used_in_sentence: The students venerate their elderly history teacher, who survived World War II and shares firsthand accounts of the era.

feisty.used_in_sentence: The feisty chihuahua wasn't afraid to stand up to dogs three times its size.
